Question_1.Context: The study focused on synthesizing flexible thermoelectric nano-composite films by incorporating inorganic copper iodide (CuI) nanosheets into a polymer matrix. The films were evaluated for their thermoelectric performance using a standard thermoelectric measurement system, ZEM-3.
Question_1.Question: What was the average lateral dimension of the CuI nanosheets?
Question_1.Source: The HRTEM image shows the presence of crystalline particles with a lattice spacing of 0.347 nm, corresponding to the (1 1 1) plane of CuI. Using Scherrer’s formula, the average crystallite size of the CuI nanosheets was calculated to be ~30 nm.

Question_2.Context: The study investigated the dispersion of CuI nanosheets in the PEDOT: PSS matrix using SEM imaging.
Question_2.Question: At what CuI fraction did the morphology of the nanocomposites show more aggregated clusters of CuI nanosheets with larger dimensions?
Question_2.Source: The morphology of the nanocomposites at 6.9 vol% of CuI showed more aggregated clusters of CuI nanosheets having larger dimensions.

Question_3.Context: The XRD analysis was performed to further characterize the nanocomposite films.
Question_3.Question: What did the XRD patterns of the nanocomposite films indicate?
Question_3.A: Successful dispersion and integration of CuI nanosheets into the PEDOT: PSS matrix.
Question_3.B: Presence of only neat PEDOT: PSS peaks.
Question_3.Source: The XRD pattern of the nanocomposite at 6.9 vol% exhibited diffraction peaks that appeared to be a combination of the patterns observed for both CuI nanosheets and neat PEDOT: PSS, indicating successful dispersion and integration of CuI nanosheets into the PEDOT: PSS matrix.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the effect of CuI nanosheets on the electrical conductivity of the nanocomposite films.
Question_4.Question: What was the electrical conductivity of the nanocomposite film with 6.9 vol% of CuI nanosheets?
Question_4.Source: The conductivity increased from 35 ± 19 S·cm-1 at 1.9 vol% of CuI to a maximum value of 852 ± 195 S·cm-1 at 6.9 vol% of CuI nanosheets.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the compositional change in the nanocomposite films using XPS measurements.
Question_5.Question: What was the PSS to PEDOT ratio in the nanocomposite film at 6.9 vol% of CuI nanosheets?
Question_5.Source: The PSS to PEDOT ratio for the nanocomposite film at 6.9 vol% of CuI was calculated to be 1.7934, indicating a reduction in the ratio compared to the pristine polymers.

Question_6.Context: The study analyzed the conformational change in the structure of PEDOT chains using Raman spectroscopy.
Question_6.Question: What did the shift in the Raman spectra of the PEDOT/CuI nanocomposite indicate?
Question_6.A: Conformational change from a coiled to an extended coiled or linear structure.
Question_6.Source: The peaks for the PEDOT/CuI nanocomposite were slightly shifted towards the red region in comparison with those for PEDOT: PSS, indicating a conformational change in the structure of the PEDOT chains from a coiled to an extended coiled or linear structure.

Question_7.Context: The study measured the carrier concentrations and mobility of the nanocomposite films using Hall measurements.
Question_7.Question: How did the carrier concentration change with increasing CuI fractions?
Question_7.A: Increased up to 6.9 vol% and then decreased.
Question_7.Source: The carrier concentration increased with the CuI fractions up to 6.9 vol%, indicating the beneficial effect of CuI in enhancing the number of charge carriers available for conduction.

Question_8.Context: The study evaluated the Seebeck coefficient of the nanocomposite films.
Question_8.Question: What was the Seebeck coefficient of the nanocomposite film with 6.9 vol% of CuI nanosheets?
Question_8.Source: The nanocomposite film with 6.9 vol% of CuI nanosheets showed a Seebeck coefficient of 14.95 µV·K-1.

Question_9.Context: The study investigated the power factor of the nanocomposite films.
Question_9.Question: At what CuI fraction did the nanocomposite film exhibit the highest power factor?
Question_9.Source: The nanocomposite film containing 6.9 vol% of CuI exhibited the highest power factor with a mean value of 19.04 µW·m-1·K-2, corresponding to the highest electrical conductivity of 852.07 S·cm-1.

Question_10.Context: The study concluded by highlighting the promising results of the PEDOT/CuI nanocomposite films for thermoelectric applications.
Question_10.Question: What was one of the key advantages of the CuI nanosheets in the nanocomposite films?
Question_10.Source: The enhancement in the power factor can be attributed to the improved electrical conductivity of 852.07 S·cm-1 in the nanocomposite film with 6.9 vol% of CuI nanosheets.
